items.question: What is a Board-Certified Pediatric Dentist?
answers: A dentist who has graduated from a 2-3 year specialty program after graduating from dental school becomes a pediatric dentist and then goes through an exam process to become board-certified. Both of our doctors are board-certified pediatric dentists by the American Board of Pediatric Dentistry and train each year to keep up to date with the latest technologies and techniques to maintain your child’s beautiful smile.

items.question: What is the right age for a child to see the dentist for the first time?
answers: The American Academy of Pediatric Dentistry and the American Medical Association, recommend that your child should see a pediatric dentist when the first tooth appears, or no later than his/her first birthday.

items.question: Why is a Pediatric Specialist better for children than a regular dentist?
answers: Pediatric dentists have the same training traditional dentists have plus an additional 2-3 years specialty training following dental school to learn specifically about treating children. We limit our practice to children of all ages and specialize in treating your infant, child, or teen including children with special needs.

items.question: Do you have sedation options for a nervous child?
answers: Our highest priority for all of our patients is centered on comfort, safety, education and positive results. Regardless of the specific plan for treatment of the teeth, the focus for the doctors and the assistants is always on using our faces, our voices and our reassuring chairside manner to better communicate. This communication is best accomplished one-on-one when the child is awake and alert.

For that reason we pride ourselves on being able to work with a wide range of children even those that are reluctant, fearful or physically or mentally compromised without the need for mind altering drugs or sedation.

items.question: Why do you make the parents wait in the waiting room away from the child?
answers: Children can sense their parent's discomfort. That is the reason why we prefer to meet the children away from their parents so that we can relate on a one-to-one basis with the child. The parent's presence in the treatment area, although intended to provide comfort to the child, instead indicates that the mom or dad is there to provide protection against these "strangers." In some cases, treatment can be seriously hindered.

items.question: What kinds of options to you have for a worn or damaged tooth?
answers: Sealants, mercury-free fillings, or crowns are some of the options available to us. We will work with you and your child to come up with a treatment solution that will balance function, esthetics, and long-term durability.

items.question: What is a sealant?
answers: A dental sealant is a protective, plastic coating applied to the chewing surface of teeth.

items.question: What do I get with my comprehensive dental exam?
answers: A comprehensive exam includes a meeting with the doctor, a comprehensive set of x-rays. Depending on whether this is your first visit, it may also include an oral hygiene instruction. We look forward to meeting you and your child. Call us today!

items.question: How often should my child see the dentist for a professional cleaning?
answers: Just like adults, we recommend children see their dentist every six months, however depending on your child's individual requirements we may adjust this schedule.

items.question: Are dental X-Rays safe for my child?
answers: There is very little risk in dental X-rays. Our state-of-the-art digital technology utilizes a fraction of the radiation used in other "film based" dental offices. We utilize lead aprons to ensure safety and minimize radiation. X-rays are highly valuable to find hidden decay, missing teeth, extra teeth, tumors and to help determine growth patters.

items.question: How should I clean my child’s teeth? What toothpaste do you recommend?
answers: Any fluoridated toothpaste that is recognized by the American Dental Association is recommended. (However, children under 3 should not generally use a fluoridated toothpaste -- they should use a non-fluoridated infant toothpaste or simply water.

items.question: Are there special dental precautions for tweens and teens I should be aware of?
answers: Be aware of lunchtime food programs at your child's school and monitor what kinds of food they're consuming both for their overall and dental health. If possible recommend rinsing with water after lunch or even better, bring a toothbrush! Homework and studying can cause stress even on younger children as schools get more competitive, bringing with it snacking at odd times and juice or other drinks that can cause staining and cavities. Suggest more healthy snacks such as popcorn, nuts, or fruit rather than packaged processed foods and drinks. Please ask us if you have additional concerns. We're happy to answer any questions you may have.

items.question: What should I do if my child knocks out a permanent tooth?
answers: The most important thing to do is to remain calm. If you have the tooth, you should attempt to insert it back into its socket and then contact us immediately. If you have difficulty re-inserting the tooth, place it in a glass of milk and contact us immediately.

items.question: Why should I fix a baby tooth if it’s just going to fall out later? Are they really that important?
answers: Baby teeth are there for a reason. They not only allow the child teeth to chew their food with, but also give proper space to their other teeth and a path for their permanent teeth to grow into. If a tooth is lost too early from an accident or due to a cavity, we may need to install a space maintainer to allow space for the new tooth to grow into. Often times, it's easier and less expensive to just repair the baby tooth.

items.question: When should my child wear a Mouth Guard?
answers: We generally recommend that a soft plastic mouth guard should be used to protect a child's teeth, lips, and cheeks from injuries during sports-related activities. During any sports based activity where there is risk of head, face or neck injury. Such sports include Hockey, Soccer, Karate, Basketball, Baseball, Skating, Skateboarding, as well as many other sports. Most oral injuries occur when children play basketball, baseball and soccer. If your child plays contact sports, we can create a custom fitted mouth guard for this purpose.

items.question: What age is the right age for orthodontics?
answers: Pediatric dentists are trained to monitor and evaluate growth and development of the teeth and supporting bone structure. As your child grows we will determine when orthodontic intervention is necessary. Every child is different and has different needs. Some children are in need of early orthodontic treatment (phase I) to help modify growth and development. Phase I can include retainers, expanders and headgear. Other children can wait for traditional braces (phase II) when they have all their permanent teeth.
